stem: A 24-year-old client is 2 days postpartum following a healthy delivery. She was discharged this morning but returns to the ED with a 'blinding headache.' Based on the documentation in the Postpartum Recovery & Neurological Surveillance tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute postpartum neurological threat.
Background: G1P1. No hypertension during pregnancy. Discharged 6 hours ago.
Assessment: Client is extremely agitated, photosensitive, and reporting 'flashes of light.'
Recommendation: Immediate magnesium protocol.

tabs.title: Postpartum Recovery Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Pressure172/112 mmHgSevere HTN
Visual AssessmentScotoma (Flashes) notedCerebral Edema
Urine Dipstick3+ ProteinProteinuria
Reflexes4+ (Very Brisk) with ClonusImpending Seizure

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 172/112, HR 102, RR 22. Edema in ankles is 3+.

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV Magnesium Sulfate for seizure prophylaxis
Assess deep tendon reflexes and implement seizure precautions
Administer high-dose Naproxen for the blinding headache
Encourage the client to pump breastmilk early to drop hormone levels

parameterOptions.text: Blood pressure and mental status monitoring
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is Postpartum Preeclampsia with Severe Features (c1). It can occur up to 6 weeks after delivery, even in women with no prior history of high blood pressure during pregnancy. The BP of 172/112, 3+ protein, and neurological irritability (4+ reflexes/headache) indicate a high risk for eclampsia. Priority actions are Magnesium (a1) to prevent seizures and safety assessments (a2). Key parameters include the BP (p1) and monitoring the subjective 'blinding' symptoms (p2).
clinicalPearls: Many cases of eclampsia actually happen AFTER the baby is born (up to 48 hours or even weeks later).
Magnesium is given to 'quiet the brain,' not primarily to drop the blood pressure.
The 'Blinding Headache' is often a sign of impending stroke in these patients.

questionTrap.trap: Treating the headache with NSAIDs like Naproxen.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NSAIDs can worsen the blood pressure in preeclamptic patients and hide the neurological 'warning sign' of the headache. Fix the underlying pressure and edema first.

mnemonic.title: Late-OB Pressure
mnemonic.expansion: L-Late onset. A-Agitated. T-Tense BP. E-Emergency Mag.
